title: Newspaper Headline
question_text: A recent headline in a national newspaper read, $$\text{Running Ten Miles a Day Lowers Blood Pressure}$$ Upon reading the article, you realize that the study had $30$ volunteer participants that normally ran $10$ miles per day, and that the results showed the participants had lower blood pressure than an average person. Which statement is false regarding the situation?

choices.text: The results cannot be generalized for the general population.
The study is done in such a way that we cannot prove a causal relationship.
The results of the study can only be generalized to people like the 30 30 volunteers.
The headline is a correct interpretation of the results of the study.
This is a prospective survey as it follows a sample of individuals into the future collecting data.

solution:
The headline is interpreting the results of a study from 30 30 volunteer participants. The participants in the study also consistently ran 10 10 miles a day. This fact leads you to the belief that since the participants were already running 10 10 miles per day, we cannot generalize the results to the whole population.

Additionally, the study is an observational study as there was no treatment imposed on the individuals in the study. Therefore, we cannot show a cause and effect relationship between running 10 10 miles per day and the lowering of blood pressure. We would need a well-designed experiment to show a causal relationship.

Choice 'D' is correct.
